p: Recent research has identified pathways by which changes in climate can affect the fundamental building blocks of economic production ( 11, 12). Empirical work has included sector-specific analyses of agriculture, labor productivity, and human health ( 12), as well as analyses of aggregate indicators such as gross domestic product (GDP) ( 4, 13). A key insight is the nonlinear response of many outcomes to temperature change, with the coolest regions often benefitting in warm years, and warmer regions being harmed. As a result, empirical evidence combined with projections of future climate change suggests that, although some wealthy countries in cooler regions could benefit from additional warming, most poor countries are likely to suffer ( 4, 14).
